author: alemaz98
content:
Hi guys, one question related to the EVM. I'm analyzing EVM bytecode taken from ethereum sepolia testnet and I find a lot of opcodes that do not correspond with any known opcode.

They are not valid opcodes, I think it's possible to upload a contract that has invalid opcodes and the EVM should revert when it finds a not known opcode. Then I found out that there is a specific opcode that is 0xFE which is the INVALID opcode.

What is the difference between INVALID 0xFE opcode and all others not known opcodes? I mean, the EVM reverts in all cases, but, a part from that, are there any other differences? And also what is the rational behind having the INVALID 0xFE opcode?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Having 0xfe as the invalid opcode is just a convention, so contract developers can be sure that this opcode WILL NEVER be assigned to anything. But yes unassigned opcodes have the same behavior as the INVALID opcode.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Are you sure you are not mistaken immediates for opcodes though? The push opcodes have immediates which can be arbitrary data

author: alemaz98
content: yes I know this thank you very much, I'm filtering out push data in order to have only opcodes. Ok so it's just a convention thanks a lot.
